elements.content: The syntheses and crystal structures of the mono­potassium salts of difluorinated and tri/perfluorinated trimesic acid (1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid ≡ H3BTC) are presented, namely, K­(H2 dF-BTC) (Fdd2, Z = 16) and K­(H2 pF-BTC) (Cc, Z = 4). For the first time, together with already known K­(H2 mF-BTC), all fluorination degrees of trimesic acid are accessible and can be used for a systematic study of the influence of fluorination on the stability of the resulting coordination polymers and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). The monopotassium salts show a decreasing (chemical) stability in water upon heating, as well as a decreasing thermal stability, as evidenced by differential scanning calorimetry/thermogravimetric analysis (DSC/TGA). A similar decreasing thermal stability is found for two series of isostructural coordination polymers (UHM-33 topology: ∞ 2[Cu2(L)2(DMA)2]·2DMA with L2– = HmF-BTC2– and HdF-BTC2–) and MOFs (∞ 3[Ba­(L)­(H2O)2]·1/2H2O with L2– = HBTC2‑, HmF-BTC2– and HdF-BTC2–). Remarkably, while the decomposition temperatures decrease with increasing fluorination of the linker, the releasing temperatures for embedded solvent molecules (DMA and H2O, respectively) increase. To identify possible candidates for the synthesis of isostructural coordination polymers and MOFs with BTC3– ligands with different degrees of fluorination, a database-adapted approach was developed, which utilizes the increased torsion angle between the carboxylate groups and the phenyl rings in these materials as a structure-determining parameter.

For the first time, together with already known K(H2 mF-BTC), all fluorination degrees of trimesic acid are accessible and can be used for a systematic study of the influence of fluorination on the stability of the resulting coordination polymers and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). The monopotassium salts show a decreasing (chemical) stability in water upon heating, as well as a decreasing thermal stability, as evidenced by differential scanning calorimetry/thermogravimetric analysis (DSC/TGA). A similar decreasing thermal stability is found for two series of isostructural coordination polymers (UHM-33 topology: ∞ 2[Cu2(L)2(DMA)2]⋅2DMA with L2- = HmF-BTC2- and HdF-BTC2-) and MOFs (∞ 3[Ba(L)(H2O)2]⋅1/2H2O with L2- = HBTC2-, HmF-BTC2- and HdF-BTC2-). Remarkably, while the decomposition temperatures decrease with increasing fluorination of the linker, the releasing temperatures for embedded solvent molecules (DMA and H2O, respectively) increase. To identify possible candidates for the synthesis of isostructural coordination polymers and MOFs with BTC3- ligands with different degrees of fluorination, a database-adapted approach was developed, which utilizes the increased torsion angle between the carboxylate groups and the phenyl rings in these materials as a structure-determining parameter.

elements.content: Three series of trimesate-based coordination polymers and MOFs with different degrees of fluorination were synthesized and structurally characterized. The comparison of the isostructural compounds clearly shows that, with increasing fluorination, the chemical and thermal stability is significantly decreased. Moreover, water or other solvent molecules are more strongly bound to the host materials with increasing fluorination, which complicates activation of these compounds, as the respective activation temperatures must be chosen very carefully.

elements.content: Since the first report on MOF-5 in 1999, the field of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has found widespread interest, because of possible applications in gas sorption, separation of gases and liquids, heterogeneous catalysis, drug encapsulation and delivery, and electronic devices. For possible industrial applications, the low thermal stability of these materials, compared to, e.g., zeolites, is still a major drawback. Accordingly, a report by Omary and co-workers on FMOF-1 with a CF3-substituted triazolate ligand received great attention; as such, fluorinated derivatives were expected to have a high thermal and chemical stability, as well as increased hydrophobicity. However, most of the important and prominent MOFs are based on aromatic carboxylate ligands, e.g., MOF-5, HKUST-1, MIL-53, or UiO-66, for which the influence of linker fluorination on their thermal stabilities is still unclear. Banerjee and co-workers investigated the influence of linker fluorination on the gas sorption properties in a series of isostructural MOFs based on 4-(1H-tetrazole-5-yl)­benzoic acid and isonicotinic acid linkers. They found that the influence of fluorination is “system-specific”. However, such systematic investigations are rare and, to the best of our knowledge, have never been performed on the chemical and thermal stability of coordination polymers (CPs) and MOFs based on aromatic carboxylate linkers such as terephthalate (BDC2–) or trimesate (BTC3–).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since the first report on MOF-5 in 1999, the field of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has found widespread interest, because of possible applications in gas sorption, separation of gases and liquids, heterogeneous catalysis, drug encapsulation and delivery, and electronic devices. For possible industrial applications, the low thermal stability of these materials, compared to, e.g., zeolites, is still a major drawback. Accordingly, a report by Omary and co-workers on FMOF-1 with a CF3-substituted triazolate ligand received great attention; as such, fluorinated derivatives were expected to have a high thermal and chemical stability, as well as increased hydrophobicity. However, most of the important and prominent MOFs are based on aromatic carboxylate ligands, e.g., MOF-5, HKUST-1, MIL-53, or UiO-66, for which the influence of linker fluorination on their thermal stabilities is still unclear. Banerjee and co-workers investigated the influence of linker fluorination on the gas sorption properties in a series of isostructural MOFs based on 4-(1H-tetrazole-5-yl)benzoic acid and isonicotinic acid linkers. They found that the influence of fluorination is "system-specific". However, such systematic investigations are rare and, to the best of our knowledge, have never been performed on the chemical and thermal stability of coordination polymers (CPs) and MOFs based on aromatic carboxylate linkers such as terephthalate (BDC2-) or trimesate (BTC3-).

elements.content: Nonetheless, numerous fluorous CPs and MOFs have been synthesized and characterized with a clear focus on materials with the perfluorinated terephthalate linker, which is readily available. Interesting luminescence and gas sorption properties were found for these materials. However, only very few investigations were reported on CPs and MOFs based on fluorinated trimesate linkers (H3BTC ≡ 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid), which is the other “fundamental” linker in the field of MOFs. This is obviously due to the fact that fluorinated trimesic acids are not readily available, despite other reports in the literature. We found that the monofluorinated acid (H3 mF-BTC) seems to be unstable, but, instead, its monopotassium salt (K­(H2 mF-BTC)) can be isolated and characterized. Based on this knowledge, we were able to synthesize and characterize a series of 14 new CPs with the mF-BTC3– ligand. Fröba and co-workers succeeded in synthesizing and characterizing a fluorinated variant of HKUST-1, named UHM-31, based on the mF-BTC3– linker. Remarkably, UHM-31 showed a significantly enhanced CO2 adsorption capacity, compared to HKUST-1, whereas the H2 and CH4 adsorption was only slightly increased. Small changes of the reaction conditions using the mF-BTC3– linker as well led to UHM-32 and UHM-33 with a three-dimensional (3D) and two-dimensional (2D) network structure.

Interesting luminescence and gas sorption properties were found for these materials. However, only very few investigations were reported on CPs and MOFs based on fluorinated trimesate linkers (H3BTC ≡ 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid), which is the other "fundamental" linker in the field of MOFs. This is obviously due to the fact that fluorinated trimesic acids are not readily available, despite other reports in the literature. We found that the monofluorinated acid (H3 mF-BTC) seems to be unstable, but, instead, its monopotassium salt (K(H2 mF-BTC)) can be isolated and characterized. Based on this knowledge, we were able to synthesize and characterize a series of 14 new CPs with the mF-BTC3- ligand. Fröba and co-workers succeeded in synthesizing and characterizing a fluorinated variant of HKUST-1, named UHM-31, based on the mF-BTC3- linker. Remarkably, UHM-31 showed a significantly enhanced CO2 adsorption capacity, compared to HKUST-1, whereas the H2 and CH4 adsorption was only slightly increased. Small changes of the reaction conditions using the mF-BTC3- linker as well led to UHM-32 and UHM-33 with a three-dimensional (3D) and two-dimensional (2D) network structure.

elements.content: During our ongoing research in this field, we have been able to synthesize and characterize the monopotassium salts of difluorinated (K­(H2 dF-BTC)) and tri/perfluorinated trimesic acid (K­(H2 pF-BTC)). With these four ligands, including nonfluorinated BTC3–, available, we have attempted to synthesize isostructural series of CPs and MOFs with different degrees of fluorination. As reported earlier, the fluorination leads an enhanced torsion angle between the carboxylate groups and the phenyl ring due to steric repulsion. This effect is most significant with a fluoro substituent in the α-position to the carboxylate group. In addition, the electron-withdrawing nature of the fluoro substituents weakens the aromaticity of the C­(phenyl)–C­(carboxylate) bond, so that the energy of the rotation barrier is reduced. Therefore, all torsion angles are significantly enlarged for perfluorinated ligands. Consequently, the synthesis of isostructural CPs and MOFs with different degrees of fluorination is difficult and only few, very selected examples have been reported in the literature until now. In the following, we will present a rational approach using the CSD database to identify suitable candidates for the synthesis of such isostructural series, which are, in a next step, used to answer the question, how linker fluorination affects the chemical and thermal stability of the resulting materials.

With these four ligands, including nonfluorinated BTC3-, available, we have attempted to synthesize isostructural series of CPs and MOFs with different degrees of fluorination. As reported earlier, the fluorination leads an enhanced torsion angle between the carboxylate groups and the phenyl ring due to steric repulsion. This effect is most significant with a fluoro substituent in the α-position to the carboxylate group. In addition, the electron-withdrawing nature of the fluoro substituents weakens the aromaticity of the C(phenyl)-C(carboxylate) bond, so that the energy of the rotation barrier is reduced. Consequently, the synthesis of isostructural CPs and MOFs with different degrees of fluorination is difficult and only few, very selected examples have been reported in the literature until now. In the following, we will present a rational approach using the CSD database to identify suitable candidates for the synthesis of such isostructural series, which are, in a next step, used to answer the question, how linker fluorination affects the chemical and thermal stability of the resulting materials.

elements.content: The syntheses of K­(H2 dF-BTC) and K­(H2 pF-BTC) mainly follow the protocol for the monopotassium salt of monofluorinated trimesic acid (K­(H2 mF-BTC)), which was published recently. 2,4-Difluoro-1,3,5-trimethylbenzene (ABCR, 98%) and 3,5-dimethyl-2,4,6-trifluorobenzoic acid (ABCR, 95%) were used as purchased, without any further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Linker Synthesis

The syntheses of K(H2 dF-BTC) and K(H2 pF-BTC) mainly follow the protocol for the monopotassium salt of monofluorinated trimesic acid (K(H2 mF-BTC)), which was published recently. 2,4-Difluoro-1,3,5-trimethylbenzene (ABCR, 98%) and 3,5-dimethyl-2,4,6-trifluorobenzoic acid (ABCR, 95%) were used as purchased, without any further purification.

elements.content: 11.0 g (69.6 mmol) of KMnO4 was suspended in 200 mL of H2O and 1.50 g (9.61 mmol) of 2,4-difluoro-1,3,5-trimethylbenzene was added dropwise. The solution was stirred under reflux for 12 h. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and H2O2 was added dropwise, until a complete decolorization of the solution was observed. The suspension was filtered and the filtrate was concentrated to 25 mL in vacuum. The solution was transferred to a Teflon flask and concentrated HCl was added dropwise, until the precipitation was completed. The precipitate was filtered off, washed with cold H2O, and dried under vacuum, giving 1 as a colorless solid. After recrystallization from H2O, colorless needle-shaped single crystals of 1 suitable for an X-ray single-crystal structure analysis were obtained (1.22 g, 4.29 mmol, 45% yield). The resulting PXRD (powder X-ray diffraction) pattern is given in the Supporting Information (see Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). 1H NMR (D2O, 300 MHz; Figure S1 in the Supporting Information): δ 8.45 (t, 1H, J = 8.3 Hz). 19F NMR (D2O, 282 MHz; Figure S2 in the Supporting Information): δ −106.73 (d, 2F, J = 8.9 Hz). Elemental analysis for C9H3F2KO6 (284.21): Calcd – C, 38.03%, H, 1.06%; Found – C, 38.24%, H, 1.05%.

elements.content: A slightly different synthesis, compared to the published protocol, was used. 99.8 mg of barium acetate (0.39 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and 82.4 mg (0.39 mmol, 1.0 equiv) of trimesic acid were mixed with 6 mL of H2O in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixture was heated to 180 °C within 2 h, held at this temperature for 10 h, and then cooled to 80 °C within 36 h and finally to room temperature within 2 h. The precipitate was filtered off and washed with H2O, and colorless crystals were manually separated from a wool-like byproduct. The resulting PXRD pattern (see Figure S11 in the Supporting Information) shows two sharp additional reflections at 2θ ≈ 31° and 40°, which could not be assigned to any possible impurities. No PXRD pattern has been given in the literature for comparison.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Coordination Polymers and MOFs

 ∞ 3[Ba(HBTC)(H2O)2]⋅1/2H2O (3)

A slightly different synthesis, compared to the published protocol, was used. 99.8 mg of barium acetate (0.39 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and 82.4 mg (0.39 mmol, 1.0 equiv) of trimesic acid were mixed with 6 mL of H2O in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixture was heated to 180 °C within 2 h, held at this temperature for 10 h, and then cooled to 80 °C within 36 h and finally to room temperature within 2 h. The precipitate was filtered off and washed with H2O, and colorless crystals were manually separated from a wool-like byproduct. The resulting PXRD pattern (see Figure S11 in the Supporting Information) shows two sharp additional reflections at 2θ ~ 31° and 40°, which could not be assigned to any possible impurities. No PXRD pattern has been given in the literature for comparison.

elements.content: 25.0 mg (0.094 mmol, 1.0 equiv) of K­(H2 mF-BTC) was dissolved in 4 mL of H2O and added to a solution of 24.0 mg (0.094 mmol, 1.0 equiv) barium acetate in 6 mL of EtOH/MeCOOH/H2O (3:2:1, v:v:v). The solution was transferred to a small beaker, which was covered with a perforated foil. The beaker was placed in a desiccator, whose bottom was filled with 50 mL of pyridine. After 3 weeks in the closed desiccator, the precipitate was filtered off, washed with EtOH/H2O (1:1 (v:v)), and dried. From this precipitate, single crystals suitable for an X-ray single-crystal structure analysis were isolated. The resulting PXRD pattern is given in the Supporting Information (Figure S12). Elemental analysis for C9H8BaFO8.5 (408.50): Calcd – C, 26.46%, H, 1.97%; Found – C, 25.97%, H, 1.86%.

elements.content: The synthesis of UHM-33 (∞ 2[Cu2(HmF-BTC)2(DMA)2]·2DMA) and dF-UHM-33 (∞ 2[Cu2(HdF-BTC)2(DMA)2]·2DMA) was performed based on the literature procedure described for UHM-33 with variations in the amount of the starting materials and the applied temperature program. K­(H2 mF-fBTC) (50.0 mg, 0.188 mmol) respectively K­(H2 dF-BTC) (1) (53.3 mg, 0.188 mmol) and Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (80.0 mg, 0.331 mmol) were mixed with 8 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixtures were heated to 60 °C at 50 °C/h, the temperature was held for 24 h before cooling to room temperature within 48 h. The obtained light blue solids were washed with DMA and air-dried. Blue single crystals of 7 suitable for an X-ray single-crystal structure analysis were isolated from this precipitate. The resulting PXRD patterns of 6 and 7 are given in the Supporting Information (Figures S17 and S18). Elemental analysis for C34H42Cu2F2N4O16 (6) (927.81): Calcd – C, 44.01%, H, 4.56%; Found – C, 44.13%, H, 4.43%. Elemental analysis for C34H40Cu2F4N4O16 (7) (963.79): Calcd – C, 42.37%, H, 4.18%; Found – C, 42.54%, H, 4.35%.

elements.content: Single crystals were isolated from the precipitates as described above. They were mounted in sealed glass capillaries on a Stoe IPDS I or Stoe IPDS II single-crystal diffractometer (T ≈ 293–295 K, Mo Kα radiation). For data collection and reduction, the Stoe program package was applied. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods using SIR-92 or SIR-2004. These structural models were completed using difference Fourier maps calculated with SHELXL-97, which was also used for all refinements. These programs were run under the WinGX system. Numerical absorption corrections were calculated and applied using X-Red and X-Shape. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. If possible, H atoms were placed on calculated positions and refined with a “riding” model. The H atoms of the water molecules in 4 and 5 could not be localized and were omitted in the refinements. In the case of disordered fluoro substituents, only F atoms were placed on these positions and refined. No additional H atoms with (1 – x) occupancy were placed on these positions. Details of all single-crystal structure analyses are given in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Single-Crystal Structure Analysis

Single crystals were isolated from the precipitates as described above. They were mounted in sealed glass capillaries on a Stoe IPDS I or Stoe IPDS II single-crystal diffractometer (T ~ 293-295 K, Mo Kα radiation). For data collection and reduction, the Stoe program package was applied. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods using SIR-92 or SIR-2004. These structural models were completed using difference Fourier maps calculated with SHELXL-97, which was also used for all refinements. These programs were run under the WinGX system. Numerical absorption corrections were calculated and applied using X-Red and X-Shape. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. If possible, H atoms were placed on calculated positions and refined with a "riding" model. The H atoms of the water molecules in 4 and 5 could not be localized and were omitted in the refinements. In the case of disordered fluoro substituents, only F atoms were placed on these positions and refined. No additional H atoms with (1 - x) occupancy were placed on these positions. Details of all single-crystal structure analyses are given in .

PXRD data were collected at room temperature on a Huber G670 diffractometer (germanium monochromator, Cu Kα1 radiation, imaging plate detector). To minimize the absorption of all compounds, measurements were performed as flat samples with the substances placed between two foils (reflections due to the foil: 2θ ≈ 21.5° and 2θ ≈ 23.7°). Typical recording times are 30 min. Employing the WinXPow software suite, the recorded patterns were compared with theoretical patterns calculated from single-crystal structure data.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD)

PXRD data were collected at room temperature on a Huber G670 diffractometer (germanium monochromator, Cu Kα1 radiation, imaging plate detector). To minimize the absorption of all compounds, measurements were performed as flat samples with the substances placed between two foils (reflections due to the foil: 2θ ~ 21.5° and 2θ ~ 23.7°). Typical recording times are 30 min. Employing the WinXPow software suite, the recorded patterns were compared with theoretical patterns calculated from single-crystal structure data.

elements.content:
Elemental analyses were performed with a CHNS Euro EA 3000 Analyzer (HEKAtech GmbH).

Thermoanalytical Investigations

Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed with a Mettler Toledo Stare DSC 1 in a constant argon stream (50 mL/min). Samples were heated with a heating rate of 10 °C/min.

Elemental Analysis

Elemental analyses were performed with a CHNS Euro EA 3000 Analyzer (HEKAtech GmbH).

Thermoanalytical Investigations

Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed with a Mettler Toledo Stare DSC 1 in a constant argon stream (50 mL/min). Samples were heated with a heating rate of 10 °C/min.

elements.content: NMR measurements were performed with a Bruker Advance II 300 MHz spectrometer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded at a frequency of 300 MHz, 19F NMR spectra at a frequency of 282 MHz. The chemical shifts (δ) are given in ppm (referenced to tetramethylsilane (TMS)).
elements.clean_text:
NMR Spectroscopy

NMR measurements were performed with a Bruker Advance II 300 MHz spectrometer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded at a frequency of 300 MHz, 19F NMR spectra at a frequency of 282 MHz. The chemical shifts (δ) are given in ppm (referenced to tetramethylsilane (TMS)).

elements.content: Based on the synthesis of K­(H2 mF-BTC) described earlier, the monopotassium salts of difluorinated and perfluorinated benzene–tricarboxylic acid were obtained. Thus, the in MOF chemistry meaningful trimesate anion is now available in all degrees of fluorination. The difluorinated linker K­(H2 dF-BTC) (1) was synthesized via oxidation of 2,4-difluoro-1,3,5-trimethylbenzene with KMnO4, according to a). However, the perfluorinated linker K­(H2 pF-BTC) (2) could not be obtained by oxidation of 2,4,6-trifluoro-1,3,5-trimethylbenzene due to the high volatility of the latter. Thus, 3,5-dimethyl-2,4,6-trifluorobenzoic acid was used as starting material instead (b). After recrystallization from H2O, single crystals of both compounds were isolated.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

K(L) with L- = H2 mF-BTC-, H2 dF-BTC- (1), H2 pF-BTC- (2)

Based on the synthesis of K(H2 mF-BTC) described earlier, the monopotassium salts of difluorinated and perfluorinated benzene-tricarboxylic acid were obtained. Thus, the in MOF chemistry meaningful  trimesate anion is now available in all degrees of fluorination. The difluorinated linker K(H2 dF-BTC) (1) was synthesized via oxidation of 2,4-difluoro-1,3,5-trimethylbenzene with KMnO4, according to a). However, the perfluorinated linker K(H2 pF-BTC) (2) could not be obtained by oxidation of 2,4,6-trifluoro-1,3,5-trimethylbenzene due to the high volatility of the latter. Thus, 3,5-dimethyl-2,4,6-trifluorobenzoic acid was used as starting material instead (b). After recrystallization from H2O, single crystals of both compounds were isolated.

elements.content: 1 crystallizes in the acentric orthorhombic space group Fdd2 (No. 43) with 16 formula units per unit cell. The ORTEP plot of 1 is shown in . The K+ cation occupies the general position 16b and is coordinated by seven oxygen atoms forming a capped trigonal prism (CTPR-7, CShM = 1.588). The K–O distances range from 2.674(3) Å to 3.340(3) Å. The coordination sphere is completed by two F atoms (K–F: 2.972(3) Å and 3.079(3) Å), leading to a 7 + 2 coordination.

elements.content: These seven oxygen atoms are stemming from the −COO– and −COOH groups of seven different anions. As a result, a 3D network with strands of edge-sharing capped trigonal KO7 prisms along the [001] axis is formed. The connectivity of these strands by the H2 dF-BTC– anions in a projection along the [100] axis is shown in . Each H2 dF-BTC– anion is coordinated by seven K+ cations. While fluorine atom F2 is disordered over two positions (), the F1 position is fully occupied and F1 bridges two K+ cations. The torsion angles between the carboxylate groups and the phenyl ring are 14.1(2)° (between F2A and F2B), 15.5(3)° (between F1 and F2B), and 55.9(3)° (between F1 and F2A). This confirms that these torsions angles are significantly increased with fluoro substituents in α-positions. Details on how these torsion angles were determined are given in the Supporting Information.

While fluorine atom F2 is disordered over two positions (), the F1 position is fully occupied and F1 bridges two K+ cations. The torsion angles between the carboxylate groups and the phenyl ring are 14.1(2)° (between F2A and F2B), 15.5(3)° (between F1 and F2B), and 55.9(3)° (between F1 and F2A). This confirms that these torsions angles are significantly increased with fluoro substituents in α-positions. Details on how these torsion angles were determined are given in the Supporting Information.

elements.content:
K­(H2 pF-BTC) (2) crystallizes in the acentric monoclinic space group Cc (No. 9) with four formula units per unit cell. The ORTEP plot of the asymmetric unit of 2 is shown in .

The K+ cation occupies the general position 4e and is coordinated by six O atoms, forming a distorted trigonal prism (TPR-6, CShM = 4.989). The K–O distances range from 2.659(4) Å to 2.896(4) Å (the seventh K–O distance is 3.540(4) Å and, thus, is 0.2 Å longer, compared to 1). As in 1, the coordination sphere is completed by two F atoms (K–F: 2.850(2) Å and 3.002(2) Å; 6 + 2 coordination), of which F3 bridges two K+ cations. All O atoms belong to the −COO– and −COOH groups of six different trimesate ligands. The resulting KO6 prisms are connected by the trimesate linkers in all spatial directions, forming a 3D network. The connectivity between the KO6 prisms and the linkers is shown in in a projection along the [100] axis. In this description, the H2 pF-BTC– ligand is coordinated by six K+ cations. The torsion angles between the carboxylate groups and the phenyl ring are 66.1(2)° (between F1 and F2), 30.5(3)° (between F1 and F3), and 48.9(3)° (between F2 and F3). Thus, significantly increased angles, compared to those observed in 1, are found.

K(H2 pF-BTC) (2) crystallizes in the acentric monoclinic space group Cc (No. 9) with four formula units per unit cell. The ORTEP plot of the asymmetric unit of 2 is shown in .

The K+ cation occupies the general position 4e and is coordinated by six O atoms, forming a distorted trigonal prism (TPR-6, CShM = 4.989). The K-O distances range from 2.659(4) Å to 2.896(4) Å (the seventh K-O distance is 3.540(4) Å and, thus, is 0.2 Å longer, compared to 1). As in 1, the coordination sphere is completed by two F atoms (K-F: 2.850(2) Å and 3.002(2) Å; 6 + 2 coordination), of which F3 bridges two K+ cations. All O atoms belong to the -COO- and -COOH groups of six different trimesate ligands. The resulting KO6 prisms are connected by the trimesate linkers in all spatial directions, forming a 3D network. The connectivity between the KO6 prisms and the linkers is shown in  in a projection along the [100] axis. In this description, the H2 pF-BTC- ligand is coordinated by six K+ cations. The torsion angles between the carboxylate groups and the phenyl ring are 66.1(2)° (between F1 and F2), 30.5(3)° (between F1 and F3), and 48.9(3)° (between F2 and F3). Thus, significantly increased angles, compared to those observed in 1, are found.

elements.content: It is notable that the crystal structures of K­(H2 mF-BTC), K­(H2 dF-BTC) (1), and K­(H2 pF-BTC) (2) show some similarities (e.g., the general assembly of cations and anions) but also distinct differences, as already indicated by the different space groups (Pc, Z = 2; Fdd2, Z = 16; Cc, Z = 4). Obviously, the increasing fluorination of the phenyl ring leads to these differences, but it is our proposal that the increasing torsion angles between the carboxylate/carboxylic acid groups and the phenyl ring, which are a consequence of the increasing fluorination, are the dominating structure-directing parameters. Therefore, in , we have collected these torsion angles for some selected compounds with BTC3– and fluorinated BTC3– ligands. The consequences will be discussed later.

The thermal stability of K­(H2 mF-BTC), K­(H2 dF-BTC) (1), and K­(H2 pF-BTC) (2) was examined using DSC/TGA investigations. As already reported, K­(H2 mF-BTC) is stable up to 310 °C in an inert atmosphere. The DSC/TGA curves (argon atmosphere) obtained for K­(H2 dF-BTC) (1) and K­(H2 pF-BTC) (2) are given as Figures S7 and S8 in the Supporting Information. The resulting curves are very similar to those of K­(H2 mF-BTC). However, the decomposition temperature is significantly shifted to lower temperatures as the degree of fluorination increases (260 °C for 1 and 250 °C for 2). This is very obvious from , where the TGA curves of all three compounds are given in one plot. This finding is contrary to the common opinion in the literature, where an enhanced thermal stability was expected with fluorination. However, this conclusion seems to be only correct for noncarboxylate ligands such as substituted triazolates that were used for the construction of FMOF-1. For aromatic carboxylate-based ligands, the fluorination weakens the C­(phenyl)–C­(carboxylate) bond so that decarboxylation can already occur at lower temperatures. A more-detailed analysis of the decomposition reactions is underway.

elements.content: To gain insight into the stability of K­(H2 mF-BTC), K­(H2 dF-BTC) (1), and K­(H2 pF-BTC) (2) under hydrothermal conditions, the following procedure was used: a small amount of the respective compound was dissolved in D2O and heated in an autoclave for 12 h at different temperatures. The resulting solution was investigated by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Using this procedure, first signals of decomposition products were obtained for K­(H2 mF-BTC) at temperatures of 100 °C and above. For 1 and 2, this decomposition temperature is drastically reduced to 60 °C (Figure S9 in the Supporting Information) and 50 °C (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information). This result has a large impact on the synthesis of coordination polymers and MOFs based on these two ligands, because hydrothermal and solvothermal syntheses above 60 and 50 °C, respectively, should be avoided, as they might reduce the yields significantly.

The resulting solution was investigated by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Using this procedure, first signals of decomposition products were obtained for K(H2 mF-BTC) at temperatures of 100 °C and above. For 1 and 2, this decomposition temperature is drastically reduced to 60 °C (Figure S9 in the Supporting Information) and 50 °C (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information). elements.content: To identify possible candidates for the synthesis of isostructural coordination polymers and MOFs with BTC3– ligands with different degrees of fluorination, we used the following approach. As already mentioned, the torsion angle between the carboxylate group and the phenyl ring is the most important structure-directing parameter for these compounds. For nonfluorinated systems, this torsion angle is very often close to zero, whereas for fluorinated compounds, significantly enhanced torsion angles are found. Therefore, we searched in the MOF subset of the CSD database for structures with nonfluorinated BTC3– ligands with enhanced torsion angles. This search led to ∞ 3[Ba­(HBTC)-(H2O)2]·1/2H2O (3) as a possible candidate, as already for the nonfluorinated compound, a mean torsion angle of 18.3° (see ) was reported obviously due to specific interactions in the lattice of this material. More details of this procedure, how suitable candidates can be identified in the CSD database, are given in the Supporting Information. ∞ 3[Ba­(HBTC)­(H2O)2]·1/2H2O (3) can be classified as a MOF, according to recent terminology, but Plater et al. already showed that water cannot be released without a (reversible) change of the crystal structure, so that N2 gas sorption isotherms only led to very small surface areas (1.86 m2/g). Nonetheless, 3 turned out to be an ideal candidate to test our approach, as isostructural 4 (with HmF-BTC2–) and 5 (with HdF-BTC2–) were obtained in pure and single crystalline form (see ) using room-temperature syntheses (see the ). All three compounds crystallize in the triclinic space group P 1 with Z = 2. In , the ORTEP plot of ∞ 3[Ba­(HmF-BTC)­(H2O)2]·1/2H2O (4) is shown. The Ba cation is located on the general position 2i; O7, O8, and O9 represent positions of water molecules and the F atom is disordered over two positions. In the difluorinated compound 5, these two positions are fully occupied.

∞ 3[Ba(L)(H2O)2]⋅1/2H2O with L2- = HBTC2- (3), HmF-BTC2- (4), HdF-BTC2- (5)

These BaO9 polyhedra are connected via common edges to form zig-zag chains running along [100] (see ). These chains are connected by the HmF-BTC2– linkers to form a 3D framework structure.

In , the crystal water molecule O9 is highlighted in red. In these projections, the [100] and [001] channels are visible, which is where O9 resides. As already mentioned, Plater et al. failed to activate the nonfluorinated compound 3. A reversible structural change occurs upon dehydration. Therefore, we have not attempted to activate isostructural 4 and 5.

elements.content: The torsion angles between the carboxylate groups and the phenyl rings in 3–5 are given in . As expected, the largest angle for 4 is found between F1A and F1B: 44.8(1)° (for labeling of atoms see ). The angles between F1A and H4 (9.1(3)°) and F1B and H4 (6.5(2)°) are significantly smaller. Similar values are found for the difluorinated compound 5: 51.6(2)° between the two fully occupied fluoro substituents and 10.9(4)° and 5.7(5)°, respectively, for the two other positions.

elements.content: To investigate the influence of fluorination on the thermal stability of 3–5, DSC/TGA data were recorded (see Figures S14–S16 in the Supporting Information). All three compounds release water in three distinct steps. The calculated mass loss for 2.5 H2O molecules (11.5% for 3, 11.0% for 4, and 10.6% for 5) is in good agreement with the plateau reached above 200 °C. The decomposition of the framework starts at higher temperatures. In , the TGA curves of 3–5 are combined in one plot. As found for K­(H2 mF-BTC), 1, and 2 (), the decomposition temperature decreases as the fluorination increases. For unfluorinated 3, it starts above 350 °C, whereas, for monofluorinated 4 (above 300 °C) and difluorinated 5 (below 300 °C), significantly decreased decomposition temperatures are found. The reasons have already been discussed earlier. On the other hand, it is remarkable that the release of H2O is shifted to higher temperatures with increasing fluorination. A close look reveals that the noncoordinating crystal water molecule O9 is released most easily in difluorinated 5however, the temperature changes are only very smallbut the release of the coordinating H2O molecules is significantly shifted to higher temperatures with increasing fluorination. Therefore, the bonding of the coordinating H2O molecules must be stronger in the fluorinated compounds. Since this finding has a significant impact on the activation of potential fluorinated MOFsthe decomposition temperature decreases and the releasing temperature of guest molecules increases with fluorination we searched for an isostructural system with guests other than water to determine if these results are transferable to nonwater guests.

elements.content: UHM-33 (∞ 2[Cu2(HmF-BTC)2(DMA)2]·2DMA, 6) was first described by Fröba and co-workers. It is a 2D coordination polymer based on the well-known Cu2 paddlewheel motif. Two DMA molecules coordinate on the axial positions of the Cu2 unit. The Cu2 units and the HmF-BTC2– linkers form an uninodal 44 net (sql topology), whose meshes are filled with two noncoordinating DMA molecules. These nets are connected by hydrogen bonding interactions. As the reported torsion angles between the phenyl ring and the carboxylate groups are already quite large (mean value of 24.6°; see ), we successfully attempted to synthesize an isostructural compound with the difluorinated ligand HdF-BTC2–, named dF-UHM-33 (7). During the unsuccessful synthesis of UHM-33 with the perfluorinated linker in DMA, we observed a decomposition of the linker at reaction temperatures of 100–120 °C, whereas the difluorinated linker turned out to be stable under these conditions. This shows that fluorination does not only reduce the chemical stability of the linker in water but also in organic solvents such as DMA. A more-detailed analysis is on the way.

[Cu2(L)2(DMA)2]⋅2DMA with L2- = HmF-BTC2- (UHM-33, 6), HdF-BTC2- (dF-UHM-33, 7)

UHM-33 (∞ 2[Cu2(HmF-BTC)2(DMA)2]⋅2DMA, 6) was first described by Fröba and co-workers. It is a 2D coordination polymer based on the well-known Cu2 paddlewheel motif. Two DMA molecules coordinate on the axial positions of the Cu2 unit. The Cu2 units and the HmF-BTC2- linkers form an uninodal 44 net (sql topology), whose meshes are filled with two noncoordinating DMA molecules. These nets are connected by hydrogen bonding interactions. As the reported torsion angles between the phenyl ring and the carboxylate groups are already quite large (mean value of 24.6°; see ), we successfully attempted to synthesize an isostructural compound with the difluorinated ligand HdF-BTC2-, named dF-UHM-33 (7). During the unsuccessful synthesis of UHM-33 with the perfluorinated linker in DMA, we observed a decomposition of the linker at reaction temperatures of 100-120 °C, whereas the difluorinated linker turned out to be stable under these conditions. This shows that fluorination does not only reduce the chemical stability of the linker in water but also in organic solvents such as DMA. A more-detailed analysis is on the way.

elements.content: 6 and 7 were obtained as single-phase samples using solvothermal reactions in DMA at 60 and 50 °C, respectively (see the ). From the resulting precipitate of 7, a single crystal was isolated. The ORTEP plot of 7 (dF-UHM-33) is shown in . The following distances were found within the Cu2 paddlewheel unit: Cu–O = 1.948(5) Å (1.959(2) Å), 1.956(5) Å (1.962(2) Å), 2x 1.960(5) Å (1.966(2) Å, 1.970(2) Å), 2.079(5) Å (2.106(2) Å); Cu–Cu = 2.676(1) Å (2.6783(5) Å). The distances for UHM-33 are given in brackets. All distances are slightly shorter in the difluorinated compound. However, note that both crystal structures were analyzed at different temperatures: for UHM-33, 153(2) K; for 7, 293(2) K). In both compounds, the fluoro substituent shows a positional disorder over all three sites. The torsion angles between the phenyl ring and the carboxylate groups are listed in . It is quite remarkable that there is almost no difference in the mean values for both compounds (24.6° vs 24.5°) and, consequently, both compounds crystallize isostructurally to each other.

elements.content: The thermal behavior of 6 and 7 was followed by DSC/TGA measurements under inert conditions (see Figures S19 and S20 in the Supporting Information). Both measurements look similar and at least three consecutive thermal events can be identified. As for the release of two DMA molecules, a mass loss of 18.08% for 7 (18.78% for 6) is calculated; the first two signals point to a stepwise release of DMA, at which the second release is directly followed by a decomposition of the material. In the black, mainly amorphous residue of 7, CuO was detected by PXRD, which should lead to a remaining mass of 17.2% (for 6) and 16.5% (for 7). Since the mass of the residue is significantly higher, the formation of amorphous copper fluorides or carbonaceous products cannot be ruled out at the moment.

elements.content: In , the TGA curves of 6 and 7 are combined in one plot. DMA is released at lower temperatures for UHM-33 (6) and the decomposition starts at lower temperatures for dF-UHM-33 (7). These results are in accordance with the results obtained for the two other isostructural series (see and ), as well as the results obtained for HKUST-1 and UHM-31, its monofluorinated isostructural derivative. With respect to applications of potential fluorinated MOFs this has the following consequences: the guests bind stronger to the MOF host with increasing fluorination, which seems to be an important improvement for gas sorption and storage and is consistent with the results obtained by Fröba and co-workers on CO2 sorption in HKUST-1 and UHM-31. However, when activating a fluorinated MOF, higher temperatures are required, which might interfere with its reduced thermal stability. Accordingly, special attention is demanded for the activation and its temperature program, as was shown in a very recent publication by us regarding UoC-1.

elements.content: Reproducible syntheses for K­(H2 dF-BTC) (monopotassium-2,4-difluoro-1,3,5-benzene-tricarboxylate) (1) and K­(H2 pF-BTC) (monopotassium-2,4,6-trifluoro-1,3,5-benzene-tricarboxylate) (2) were developed. Thus, the trimesate linker very frequently used for the construction of coordination polymers and MOFs is now available in all degrees of fluorination. The crystal structures of 1 and 2 were solved and refined from X-ray single-crystal diffraction data, and their thermal stability was investigated under inert (argon atmosphere) and hydrothermal conditions. Both reveal a decreasing stability with an increasing degree of fluorination. Starting from these fluorinated trimesate linkers, two series of isostructural coordination polymers and MOFs with different degrees of fluorination were synthesized and characterized based on the known congeners ∞ 3[Ba­(HBTC)­(H2O)2]·1/2H2O (3) and UHM-33 (6). Their thermal stabilities were investigated by means of DSC/TGA measurements under inert conditions (argon atmosphere). As found for 1 and 2, the thermal stabilities of 3–5 (∞ 3[Ba­(L)­(H2O)2]·1/2H2O with L2– = HBTC2– (3), HmF-BTC2– (4), and HdF-BTC2– (5)), as well as 6 and 7 (∞ 2[Cu2(HmF-BTC)2(DMA)2]·2DMA, UHM-33, 6 and ∞ 2[Cu2(HdF-BTC)2(DMA)2]·2DMA, 7) also decrease as the fluorination increases. This finding is inconsistent with reports in the literature. However, these reports mainly refer to FMOF-1, which is constructed from a CF3-substituted triazolate ligand. With aromatic carboxylate-based ligands, the thermal (and chemical) stability is inverted, because increasing fluorination due to the withdrawing nature of the fluoro substituent facilitates decarboxylation of the material. In addition, the release of coordinated and uncoordinated solvent molecules occurs at higher temperatures with increasing fluorination of the ligand. This finding has a large impact on the activation of such fluorinated MOFs: as the release of solvent molecules starts at higher temperatures, whereas the decomposition temperatures are shifted to lower temperatures, the activation conditions for these MOFs must be chosen very carefully. On the other hand, the higher release temperatures for solvent molecules in fluorinated MOFs point to a stronger interaction between the guest and the MOF host. This makes fluorinated MOFs still attractive candidates for gas sorption, as was already shown for CO2 sorption in UHM-31, which is a fluorinated variant of HKUST-1. Currently, we are working on the synthesis of further examples of isostructural MOFs with different degrees of fluorination in order to investigate the influence of fluoro substituents on their gas sorption properties in more detail.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Reproducible syntheses for K(H2 dF-BTC) (monopotassium-2,4-difluoro-1,3,5-benzene-tricarboxylate) (1) and K(H2 pF-BTC) (monopotassium-2,4,6-trifluoro-1,3,5-benzene-tricarboxylate) (2) were developed. Thus, the trimesate linker very frequently used for the construction of coordination polymers and MOFs is now available in all degrees of fluorination. The crystal structures of 1 and 2 were solved and refined from X-ray single-crystal diffraction data, and their thermal stability was investigated under inert (argon atmosphere) and hydrothermal conditions. Both reveal a decreasing stability with an increasing degree of fluorination. Starting from these fluorinated trimesate linkers, two series of isostructural coordination polymers and MOFs with different degrees of fluorination were synthesized and characterized based on the known congeners ∞ 3[Ba(HBTC)(H2O)2]⋅1/2H2O (3) and UHM-33 (6). Their thermal stabilities were investigated by means of DSC/TGA measurements under inert conditions (argon atmosphere). As found for 1 and 2, the thermal stabilities of 3-5 (∞ 3[Ba(L)(H2O)2]⋅1/2H2O with L2- = HBTC2- (3), HmF-BTC2- (4), and HdF-BTC2- (5)), as well as 6 and 7 (∞ 2[Cu2(HmF-BTC)2(DMA)2]⋅2DMA, UHM-33, 6 and ∞ 2[Cu2(HdF-BTC)2(DMA)2]⋅2DMA, 7) also decrease as the fluorination increases. This finding is inconsistent with reports in the literature. However, these reports mainly refer to FMOF-1, which is constructed from a CF3-substituted triazolate ligand. With aromatic carboxylate-based ligands, the thermal (and chemical) stability is inverted, because increasing fluorination due to the withdrawing nature of the fluoro substituent facilitates decarboxylation of the material. In addition, the release of coordinated and uncoordinated solvent molecules occurs at higher temperatures with increasing fluorination of the ligand. This finding has a large impact on the activation of such fluorinated MOFs: as the release of solvent molecules starts at higher temperatures, whereas the decomposition temperatures are shifted to lower temperatures, the activation conditions for these MOFs must be chosen very carefully. On the other hand, the higher release temperatures for solvent molecules in fluorinated MOFs point to a stronger interaction between the guest and the MOF host. This makes fluorinated MOFs still attractive candidates for gas sorption, as was already shown for CO2 sorption in UHM-31, which is a fluorinated variant of HKUST-1. Currently, we are working on the synthesis of further examples of isostructural MOFs with different degrees of fluorination in order to investigate the influence of fluoro substituents on their gas sorption properties in more detail.

elements.content: To find possible candidates for the synthesis of such isostructural series of MOFs with an increasing degree of fluorination, we developed a straightforward database-driven approach. It is well-known that, with increasing fluorination, the torsion angles between the carboxylate groups and the phenyl rings increase. In , the respective torsion angles for some trimesate-based coordination polymers and MOFs are summarized. It is striking that, for isostructural systems, these angles only vary by a few degrees (e.g., 18.3° in 3, 20.1° in 4, and 22.7° in 5; Δ = 4.4°), whereas for nonisostructural series much larger variations are found (e.g., 21.6° in K­(H2 mF-BTC), 28.5° in 2, and 48.5° in 3; Δ = 26.9°). Consequently, all our attempts to synthesize an analogue of HKUST-1 with dF-BTC3– or pF-BTC3– ligands failed, as the torsion angle of 5.5° in nonfluorinated HKUST-1 is obviously too small to accommodate a ligand with two or three fluoro substituents. On the other hand, “packing effects”, etc., lead to coordination polymers and MOFs with already larger torsion angles with nonfluorinated ligands. It is our proposal that these materials with enhanced torsion angles, which can easily be identified in the suitable databases, are ideal candidates for the synthesis of such isostructural series. At the moment, it is unclear why, in some compounds, these angles are almost “fixed” and do not vary, whereas in others, significantly larger variations are found. Detailed calculations on the lattice energies of such systems might shed some light on these open questions.

11.0 g (69.6 mmol) of KMnO4 was suspended in 200 mL of H2O and 1.50 g (9.61 mmol) of 2,4-difluoro-1,3,5-trimethylbenzene was added dropwise. The solution was stirred under reflux for 12 h. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and H2O2 was added dropwise, until a complete decolorization of the solution was observed. The suspension was filtered and the filtrate was concentrated to 25 mL in vacuum. The solution was transferred to a Teflon flask and concentrated HCl was added dropwise, until the precipitation was completed. The precipitate was filtered off, washed with cold H2O, and dried under vacuum, giving 1 as a colorless solid. After recrystallization from H2O, colorless needle-shaped single crystals of 1 suitable for an X-ray single-crystal structure analysis were obtained (1.22 g, 4.29 mmol, 45% yield). The resulting PXRD (powder X-ray diffraction) pattern is given in the Supporting Information (see Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). 1H NMR (D2O, 300 MHz; Figure S1 in the Supporting Information): δ 8.45 (t, 1H, J = 8.3 Hz). 19F NMR (D2O, 282 MHz; Figure S2 in the Supporting Information): δ −106.73 (d, 2F, J = 8.9 Hz). Elemental analysis for C9H3F2KO6 (284.21): Calcd – C, 38.03%, H, 1.06%; Found – C, 38.24%, H, 1.05%.

K­(H<sub>2</sub> <italic>pF</italic>-BTC) (<bold>2</bold>)

4.6 g (29.1 mmol) of KMnO4 was suspended in 250 mL of H2O and 1.00 g (4.9 mmol) of 3,5-dimethyl-2,4,6-trifluorobenzoic acid was added dropwise. The solution was stirred under reflux for 12 h. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and H2O2 was added dropwise, until a complete decolorization of the solution was observed. The suspension was filtered and the filtrate was concentrated to 10 mL in vacuum. The solution was transferred to a Teflon flask and concentrated HCl was added dropwise, until the precipitation was completed. The precipitate was filtered off, washed with cold H2O, and dried under vacuum, giving 2 as a colorless solid. After recrystallization from H2O, colorless needle-shaped single crystals of 2 suitable for an X-ray single-crystal structure analysis were obtained (0.74 g, 2.45 mmol, 50% yield). The resulting PXRD pattern is given in the Supporting Information (see Figure S6). 1H NMR (D2O, 300 MHz; Figure S3 in the Supporting Information): no proton signal. 19F NMR (D2O, 282 MHz; Figure S4 in the Supporting Information): δ −108.47 (s, 3F). Elemental analysis for C9H2F3KO6 (302.20): Calcd – C, 35.77%, H, 0.67%; Found – C, 35.37%, H, 0.72%.

Synthesis of Coordination Polymers and MOFs <sub arrange="stack">∞</sub> <sup arrange="stack">3</sup>[Ba­(HBTC)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

A slightly different synthesis, compared to the published protocol, was used. 99.8 mg of barium acetate (0.39 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and 82.4 mg (0.39 mmol, 1.0 equiv) of trimesic acid were mixed with 6 mL of H2O in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixture was heated to 180 °C within 2 h, held at this temperature for 10 h, and then cooled to 80 °C within 36 h and finally to room temperature within 2 h. The precipitate was filtered off and washed with H2O, and colorless crystals were manually separated from a wool-like byproduct. The resulting PXRD pattern (see Figure S11 in the Supporting Information) shows two sharp additional reflections at 2θ ≈ 31° and 40°, which could not be assigned to any possible impurities. No PXRD pattern has been given in the literature for comparison.

<sub arrange="stack">∞</sub> <sup arrange="stack">3</sup>[Ba­(H<italic>mF</italic>-BTC)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

25.0 mg (0.094 mmol, 1.0 equiv) of K­(H2 mF-BTC) was dissolved in 4 mL of H2O and added to a solution of 24.0 mg (0.094 mmol, 1.0 equiv) barium acetate in 6 mL of EtOH/MeCOOH/H2O (3:2:1, v:v:v). The solution was transferred to a small beaker, which was covered with a perforated foil. The beaker was placed in a desiccator, whose bottom was filled with 50 mL of pyridine. After 3 weeks in the closed desiccator, the precipitate was filtered off, washed with EtOH/H2O (1:1 (v:v)), and dried. From this precipitate, single crystals suitable for an X-ray single-crystal structure analysis were isolated. The resulting PXRD pattern is given in the Supporting Information (Figure S12). Elemental analysis for C9H8BaFO8.5 (408.50): Calcd – C, 26.46%, H, 1.97%; Found – C, 25.97%, H, 1.86%.

<sub arrange="stack">∞</sub> <sup arrange="stack">3</sup>[Ba­(H<italic>dF</italic>-BTC)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

39.1 mg (0.15 mmol, 1.0 equiv) Ba­(NO3)2 were dissolved in 1 mL of H2O and added to a solution of 42.7 mg of K­(H2 dF-BTC) (1) (0.15 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in 17 mL of H2O. The combined solutions (pH ∼4) were transferred to a Petri dish, which was covered with a perforated foil. After 1 week, colorless needle-shaped crystal were obtained, which were washed with H2O and dried. These crystals were suitable for an X-ray single-crystal structure analysis. The resulting PXRD pattern is given in the Supporting Information (Figure S13). Elemental analysis for C9H7BaF2O8.5 (426.49): Calcd – C, 25.35%, H, 1.65%; Found – C, 25.47%, H, 1.52%.

UHM-33 (<bold>6</bold>)/<italic>dF</italic>-UHM-33 (<bold>7</bold>)

The synthesis of UHM-33 (∞ 2[Cu2(HmF-BTC)2(DMA)2]·2DMA) and dF-UHM-33 (∞ 2[Cu2(HdF-BTC)2(DMA)2]·2DMA) was performed based on the literature procedure described for UHM-33 with variations in the amount of the starting materials and the applied temperature program. K­(H2 mF-fBTC) (50.0 mg, 0.188 mmol) respectively K­(H2 dF-BTC) (1) (53.3 mg, 0.188 mmol) and Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (80.0 mg, 0.331 mmol) were mixed with 8 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixtures were heated to 60 °C at 50 °C/h, the temperature was held for 24 h before cooling to room temperature within 48 h. The obtained light blue solids were washed with DMA and air-dried. Blue single crystals of 7 suitable for an X-ray single-crystal structure analysis were isolated from this precipitate. The resulting PXRD patterns of 6 and 7 are given in the Supporting Information (Figures S17 and S18). Elemental analysis for C34H42Cu2F2N4O16 (6) (927.81): Calcd – C, 44.01%, H, 4.56%; Found – C, 44.13%, H, 4.43%. Elemental analysis for C34H40Cu2F4N4O16 (7) (963.79): Calcd – C, 42.37%, H, 4.18%; Found – C, 42.54%, H, 4.35%.

K(H2 pF-BTC) (2) 

4.6 g (29.1 mmol) of KMnO4 was suspended in 250 mL of H2O and 1.00 g (4.9 mmol) of 3,5-dimethyl-2,4,6-trifluorobenzoic acid was added dropwise. The solution was stirred under reflux for 12 h. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and H2O2 was added dropwise, until a complete decolorization of the solution was observed. The suspension was filtered and the filtrate was concentrated to 10 mL in vacuum. The solution was transferred to a Teflon flask and concentrated HCl was added dropwise, until the precipitation was completed. The precipitate was filtered off, washed with cold H2O, and dried under vacuum, giving 2 as a colorless solid. After recrystallization from H2O, colorless needle-shaped single crystals of 2 suitable for an X-ray single-crystal structure analysis were obtained (0.74 g, 2.45 mmol, 50% yield). The resulting PXRD pattern is given in the Supporting Information (see Figure S6). 1H NMR (D2O, 300 MHz; Figure S3 in the Supporting Information): no proton signal. 19F NMR (D2O, 282 MHz; Figure S4 in the Supporting Information): δ -108.47 (s, 3F). Elemental analysis for C9H2F3KO6 (302.20): Calcd - C, 35.77%, H, 0.67%; Found - C, 35.37%, H, 0.72%.

Synthesis of Coordination Polymers and MOFs

 ∞ 3[Ba(HBTC)(H2O)2]⋅1/2H2O (3)

A slightly different synthesis, compared to the published protocol, was used. 99.8 mg of barium acetate (0.39 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and 82.4 mg (0.39 mmol, 1.0 equiv) of trimesic acid were mixed with 6 mL of H2O in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixture was heated to 180 °C within 2 h, held at this temperature for 10 h, and then cooled to 80 °C within 36 h and finally to room temperature within 2 h. The precipitate was filtered off and washed with H2O, and colorless crystals were manually separated from a wool-like byproduct. The resulting PXRD pattern (see Figure S11 in the Supporting Information) shows two sharp additional reflections at 2θ ~ 31° and 40°, which could not be assigned to any possible impurities. No PXRD pattern has been given in the literature for comparison. 

 ∞ 3[Ba(HmF-BTC)(H2O)2]⋅1/2H2O (4)

25.0 mg (0.094 mmol, 1.0 equiv) of K(H2 mF-BTC) was dissolved in 4 mL of H2O and added to a solution of 24.0 mg (0.094 mmol, 1.0 equiv) barium acetate in 6 mL of EtOH/MeCOOH/H2O (3:2:1, v:v:v). The solution was transferred to a small beaker, which was covered with a perforated foil. The beaker was placed in a desiccator, whose bottom was filled with 50 mL of pyridine. After 3 weeks in the closed desiccator, the precipitate was filtered off, washed with EtOH/H2O (1:1 (v:v)), and dried. From this precipitate, single crystals suitable for an X-ray single-crystal structure analysis were isolated. The resulting PXRD pattern is given in the Supporting Information (Figure S12). Elemental analysis for C9H8BaFO8.5 (408.50): Calcd - C, 26.46%, H, 1.97%; Found - C, 25.97%, H, 1.86%.

 ∞ 3[Ba(HdF-BTC)(H2O)2]⋅1/2H2O (5)

39.1 mg (0.15 mmol, 1.0 equiv) Ba(NO3)2 were dissolved in 1 mL of H2O and added to a solution of 42.7 mg of K(H2 dF-BTC) (1) (0.15 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in 17 mL of H2O. The combined solutions (pH ~4) were transferred to a Petri dish, which was covered with a perforated foil. After 1 week, colorless needle-shaped crystal were obtained, which were washed with H2O and dried. These crystals were suitable for an X-ray single-crystal structure analysis. The resulting PXRD pattern is given in the Supporting Information (Figure S13). Elemental analysis for C9H7BaF2O8.5 (426.49): Calcd - C, 25.35%, H, 1.65%; Found - C, 25.47%, H, 1.52%.

UHM-33 (6)/dF-UHM-33 (7)

The synthesis of UHM-33 (∞ 2[Cu2(HmF-BTC)2(DMA)2]⋅2DMA) and dF-UHM-33 (∞ 2[Cu2(HdF-BTC)2(DMA)2]⋅2DMA) was performed based on the literature procedure described for UHM-33 with variations in the amount of the starting materials and the applied temperature program. K(H2 mF-fBTC) (50.0 mg, 0.188 mmol) respectively K(H2 dF-BTC) (1) (53.3 mg, 0.188 mmol) and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (80.0 mg, 0.331 mmol) were mixed with 8 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixtures were heated to 60 °C at 50 °C/h, the temperature was held for 24 h before cooling to room temperature within 48 h. The obtained light blue solids were washed with DMA and air-dried. Blue single crystals of 7 suitable for an X-ray single-crystal structure analysis were isolated from this precipitate. The resulting PXRD patterns of 6 and 7 are given in the Supporting Information (Figures S17 and S18). Elemental analysis for C34H42Cu2F2N4O16 (6) (927.81): Calcd - C, 44.01%, H, 4.56%; Found - C, 44.13%, H, 4.43%. Elemental analysis for C34H40Cu2F4N4O16 (7) (963.79): Calcd - C, 42.37%, H, 4.18%; Found - C, 42.54%, H, 4.35%.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stability of K­(H2 mF-BTC), K­(H2 dF-BTC) (1), and K­(H2 pF-BTC) (2) was examined using DSC/TGA investigations. As already reported, K­(H2 mF-BTC) is stable up to 310 °C in an inert atmosphere. The DSC/TGA curves (argon atmosphere) obtained for K­(H2 dF-BTC) (1) and K­(H2 pF-BTC) (2) are given as Figures S7 and S8 in the Supporting Information. The resulting curves are very similar to those of K­(H2 mF-BTC). However, the decomposition temperature is significantly shifted to lower temperatures as the degree of fluorination increases (260 °C for 1 and 250 °C for 2). This is very obvious from , where the TGA curves of all three compounds are given in one plot. This finding is contrary to the common opinion in the literature, where an enhanced thermal stability was expected with fluorination. However, this conclusion seems to be only correct for noncarboxylate ligands such as substituted triazolates that were used for the construction of FMOF-1. For aromatic carboxylate-based ligands, the fluorination weakens the C­(phenyl)–C­(carboxylate) bond so that decarboxylation can already occur at lower temperatures. A more-detailed analysis of the decomposition reactions is underway.

To investigate the influence of fluorination on the thermal stability of 3–5, DSC/TGA data were recorded (see Figures S14–S16 in the Supporting Information). All three compounds release water in three distinct steps. The calculated mass loss for 2.5 H2O molecules (11.5% for 3, 11.0% for 4, and 10.6% for 5) is in good agreement with the plateau reached above 200 °C. The decomposition of the framework starts at higher temperatures. In , the TGA curves of 3–5 are combined in one plot. As found for K­(H2 mF-BTC), 1, and 2 (), the decomposition temperature decreases as the fluorination increases. For unfluorinated 3, it starts above 350 °C, whereas, for monofluorinated 4 (above 300 °C) and difluorinated 5 (below 300 °C), significantly decreased decomposition temperatures are found. The reasons have already been discussed earlier. On the other hand, it is remarkable that the release of H2O is shifted to higher temperatures with increasing fluorination. A close look reveals that the noncoordinating crystal water molecule O9 is released most easily in difluorinated 5however, the temperature changes are only very smallbut the release of the coordinating H2O molecules is significantly shifted to higher temperatures with increasing fluorination. Therefore, the bonding of the coordinating H2O molecules must be stronger in the fluorinated compounds. Since this finding has a significant impact on the activation of potential fluorinated MOFsthe decomposition temperature decreases and the releasing temperature of guest molecules increases with fluorination we searched for an isostructural system with guests other than water to determine if these results are transferable to nonwater guests.

The thermal behavior of 6 and 7 was followed by DSC/TGA measurements under inert conditions (see Figures S19 and S20 in the Supporting Information). Both measurements look similar and at least three consecutive thermal events can be identified. As for the release of two DMA molecules, a mass loss of 18.08% for 7 (18.78% for 6) is calculated; the first two signals point to a stepwise release of DMA, at which the second release is directly followed by a decomposition of the material. In the black, mainly amorphous residue of 7, CuO was detected by PXRD, which should lead to a remaining mass of 17.2% (for 6) and 16.5% (for 7). Since the mass of the residue is significantly higher, the formation of amorphous copper fluorides or carbonaceous products cannot be ruled out at the moment.

For aromatic carboxylate-based ligands, the fluorination weakens the C(phenyl)-C(carboxylate) bond so that decarboxylation can already occur at lower temperatures.
